section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children through dance, and introduce vocabulary (adventure, wild).
Begin Story Time by introducing the Big Book and asking, What did Eliot pretend to do?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Understand that people who speak the same language sometimes use different dialects or expressions.
Try a new approach or new task.
Relate own experiences to those in books; Ask and answer questions about story elements.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to identify different kinds of destinations where they might like to have an adventure.
Discuss different environments and how they might affect an adventure.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book has a character that goes on an adventure? What kind of adventure is it?
What kind of pretend adventure is your favorite? Where will you go?
What would a footprint from your shoe look like? Can you draw it?
What kind of adventure would you like to go on? Who will go with you?
Can you make a pretend sailboat out of clay? How will you make the sails?
Point to the letter that makes the first sound in wild.
Use blocks to make a city with concrete giants.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder persist in tasks and introduce vocabulary (new idea, solve problems).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to The Greatest Adventure.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of text read aloud.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use complete sentences of four or more words; Recognize and understand common cognates.
Persist in tasks.
Try a new approach or new task.
Relate own experiences to those in books.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Vocabulary; Listening; Conversation; Sentence Structure

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show pages in the Big Book that highlight the Mind Builder, persist in tasks.
Have children discuss what types of adventures they have gone on where they had to be persistent.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Show me a story with a picture of something you’d like to learn.
Can you pretend to look for animal tracks?
Can you count the number of animals there were in the book we read today?
What would happen if the paper dragon in the book were real? Can you write or draw a story about it?
Can you make a paper dragon? What are its features?
Show me the letter that makes the first sound in dragon.
Can you build a concrete giant like in today’s book?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Greatest Adventure by Tony Piedra. Copyright © 2018 by Tony Piedra. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary (tracked, trails).
Begin Story Time by revisiting The Greatest Adventure and asking the guiding question, What did you learn about Eliot’s grandfather’s boat?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Persist in tasks.
Try a new approach or new task.
Blend two or more syllables to create words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children name and discuss pictures of animals.
Have children group the cards into animals that are wild and animals that are not wild.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the animals in that book the same? Different?
Pretend you are playing with your pet kitten. How would you take care of a kitten?
What is the biggest wild animal you can think of?
What kind of pet do you have or would you like to have? Why? Write about it.
How many wild animals can you name? Can you draw and color two?
What letters makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the words tracked and trails?
How can you build a dog house using blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Greatest Adventure by Tony Piedra. Copyright © 2018 by Tony Piedra. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: I Want To...

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background on what children have learned this year and introduce vocabulary words (count, art).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts I Want To... and The Greatest Adventure.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, We’re ready. What’s next?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Try a new approach or new task.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to identify different jobs in the community and discuss what each person does.
Discuss if children would like to do that job and why.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is the doctor doing in that book? What other books have doctors in them?
Pretend you’re riding on a fast train. How does it feel?
Can you make a long train with connecting cubes? How many connecting cubes are there in your train?
Which activity do you want to learn the most? Can you write about it?
Can you use paper to make an airplane? Can you fly your plane?
What word can you add to sail to make a new word? Can you find the letters?
Can you build a big clock? What numbers will it have?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Greatest Adventure by Tony Piedra. Copyright © 2018 by Tony Piedra. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out pages from the book and to introduce vocabulary words (perfect, anchor).
Begin Story Time by revisiting The Greatest Adventure and asking, What did Eliot and his grandfather do together?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What new task would you like to learn?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about an adventure, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend to be a cashier and give a shopper change?
What does a scientist do? What kind of tools do they use?
Write a story about the perfect adventure.
Imagine what you want to be when you grow up. Draw a picture about it.
What is your favorite animal? Can you find the letters for the name of the animal and put them in order to make the word?
What materials could you use to build a boat like Eliot’s grandfather’s boat?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Greatest Adventure by Tony Piedra. Copyright © 2018 by Tony Piedra. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Try a new approach or new task.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Respond to different musical styles through movement and play.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Try a new approach or new task.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversational rules.
Demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal conversational rules.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Try a new approach or new task.
Blend syllables into words.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversational rules.
Demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal conversational rules.
Try a new approach or new task.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Try a new approach or new task.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
